extraction_metadata.article_title: Competition Among Proprietary and Open-Source Software Firms: The Role of Licensing in Strategic Contribution

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: OSSg2 (Second-generation open-source) - A professional open-source business model where profit-motivated firms are driven by revenues stemming from a market for professional services, characterized by firms that typically generate the bulk of their revenues by providing complementary services around their products and own or tightly control the software code to exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service than could potential competing service providers.
synonyms_found: services-based business models built on open-source software
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'This professional open-source business model, where profit-motivated firms are driven by revenues stemming from a market for professional services, is not a new one... Watson et al. (2008, p.43) refer to this type of OSS business model as second-generation open-source or OSSg2, characterized by firms that typically generate the bulk of their revenues by providing complementary services around their products and own or tightly control the software code and can exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service than could potential competing service providers.'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_value: professional open-source business model
second-generation open-source
OSSg2
services-based business models built on open-source software
synonyms_found: services-based business models built on open-source software

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?

extracted_data.question_text: What is the intellectual property regime adopted by the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'For example, the GNU General Public License (GPL) is a widely employed open-source license that is considered to be quite restrictive with regard to what a contributor can do with the software. On the other end of the spectrum lies the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD) license, which imposes minimal restrictions on anyone who uses or extends BSD-licensed software'

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Professional services and management tools for enterprise software
Customer Segment: Enterprise customers requiring software integration services
Revenue Streams: Service revenue from professional services
Key Activities: Software development, service provision, strategic contributions
Key Resources: Intimate knowledge of software code, development expertise
Cost Structure: Production costs shared between originator and contributor
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'selling management tools and services that make it easier to run Kafka to enterprise customers' | Page 1: 'enterprise customers (Konrad 2015)' | Page 1: 'revenues stemming from a market for professional services' | Page 1: 'strategic development efforts made by these firms largely codetermine the qualities of the fully integrated software solutions' | Page 1: 'exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service' | Page 1: 'the OSS originator and contributor share production costs'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Proprietor | Sole service provider for proprietary software | Competes with OSS providers | Charges for product itself | OSS Originator | Develops and manages OSS | Collaborates with contributor on development | Competes with contributor for services | OSS Contributor | Strategically contributes to OSS | Collaborates with originator on development | Competes with originator for services
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'we study three-way competition among a proprietary firm (proprietor), an OSS originating firm (originator), and an OSS contributing firm (contributor)' | Page 1: 'They collaborate on the development and management of enterprise OSS but then compete against each other in the services market' | Page 1: 'the proprietor solely incurs production costs but then retains significant pricing power because it can charge for the product itself' | Page 1: 'the OSS originator and contributor share production costs, cannot charge for an open-source product, and must compete for service revenues'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Service revenue generation
Competitive advantage through intimate code knowledge
Ability to provide higher-quality services than competitors
Profit motivation from professional services market
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'profit-motivated firms are driven by revenues stemming from a market for professional services' | Page 1: 'own or tightly control the software code and can exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service than could potential competing service providers' | Page 1: 'the economic incentives underlying these business models are commonly related to service revenue generation'

extracted_value: Open-source software foundation → Enables collaborative development
Service market demand → Drives revenue generation
Development expertise → Enables quality service provision
Strategic contribution capability → Allows competitive positioning
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'services-based business models built on open-source software (OSS)' | Page 1: 'revenues stemming from a market for professional services' | Page 1: 'exploit their intimate knowledge of the code to provide higher-quality service' | Page 1: 'third-party firms can also strategically contribute to OSS and compete in the services market'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Cannot charge for open-source product → Must rely on service revenues
License restrictiveness → Can exacerbate incentive conflicts between originator and contributor
Production cost sharing → Reduces individual pricing power
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'For all practical purposes, OSS-based business models typically preclude charging for the software alone' | Page 1: 'it is not always in the best interest of the originator for the contributor to invest greater development effort, such licensing can actually be detrimental to both consumer surplus and social welfare when it exacerbates this incentive conflict' | Page 1: 'the OSS originator and contributor share production costs, cannot charge for an open-source product, and must compete for service revenues'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Incentive conflicts between originator and contributor
Complex competitive dynamics with proprietary firms
License restrictiveness affecting collaborative efforts
Balancing collaboration and competition in services market
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'it is not always in the best interest of the originator for the contributor to invest greater development effort, such licensing can actually be detrimental to both consumer surplus and social welfare when it exacerbates this incentive conflict' | Page 1: 'the nature of competition between OSS constituents and proprietary software firms can be complex' | Page 1: 'They collaborate on the development and management of enterprise OSS but then compete against each other in the services market'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Strategic licensing choices → Mitigate incentive conflicts → Improve collaborative outcomes
Quality investment coordination → Address competitive dynamics → Enhance market position
Service expertise development → Overcome revenue limitations → Create competitive advantage

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of evidence presented in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We study a three-player game and examine how open-source licensing affects competition among an open-source originator, an open-source contributor, and a proprietor competing in an enterprise software market' | Page 1: 'The cofounders of Apache Kafka... are also the cofounders of Confluent' | Page 1: 'JBoss, which in 1999 successfully built a company on top of open-source software (OSS)'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_value: Confluent → Built business on Apache Kafka services
JBoss → Enterprise Java application server product
Apache Kafka → Open-source platform for real-time data streams
Salesforce → Proprietary CRM software
SugarCRM → OSS originator in CRM market
Synolia → OSS contributor in CRM market
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The cofounders of Apache Kafka, an open-source platform for handling real-time data streams, are also the cofounders of Confluent, a firm that has built a business based on selling management tools and services that make it easier to run Kafka to enterprise customers' | Page 1: 'JBoss, which in 1999 successfully built a company on top of open-source software (OSS), driven purely by the provision of services for its enterprise Java application server product' | Page 1: 'one can think of Salesforce as the proprietor, SugarCRM as the OSS originator, and Synolia as the OSS contributor'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Permissive licensing model → Minimal restrictions on software use and extension
Restrictive licensing model → Significant restrictions on contributor activities
Dual licensing scheme → Different licensing terms for different use cases
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'the GNU General Public License (GPL) is a widely employed open-source license that is considered to be quite restrictive with regard to what a contributor can do with the software. On the other end of the spectrum lies the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD) license, which imposes minimal restrictions on anyone who uses or extends BSD-licensed software' | Page 1: 'OSS is offered under either a dual licensing scheme or a support model'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Increasing adoption of services-based business models built on open-source software
Growing complexity of competition between OSS constituents and proprietary software firms
Evolving role of licensing in strategic contributions and competitive dynamics
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'firms are increasingly using services-based business models built on open-source software (OSS) to compete with established, proprietary software firms' | Page 1: 'the nature of competition between OSS constituents and proprietary software firms can be complex' | Page 1: 'their incentives are likely influenced by the licensing schemes that govern OSS'
